==Government==
===Local government=== [[File:AustinFireStation1.JPG|left|thumb|[[Austin Central Fire Station 1]]]] The [[Austin, Texas#Government and law|city hall]] is located in Downtown Austin and is the administrative office of Austin. Originally built in 1871, the city hall was demolished and rebuilt multiple times before the current one was built in November 2004.<ref name=firstcityhall>{{cite web|title=Austin City Hall|url=http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/cityhall/cityhall.htm|publisher=The City of Austin|accessdate=June 27, 2011}}</ref><ref name=currentcityhall>{{cite web|title=2nd Street District|url=http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/cityhall/2ndstreet.htm|publisher=The City of Austin|accessdate=June 27, 2011}}</ref> The current city hall cost $55.6 million to build and contains a total of seven stories, of which three are underground.<ref name=cityhallquickfacts>{{cite web|title=About City Hall|url=http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/cityhall/about.htm|publisher=The City of Austin|accessdate=June 27, 2011}}</ref> Within the building, [[city council]] meetings take place in the council chambers.<ref name=councilchambers>{{cite web|title=Council Chambers|url=http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/cityhall/features.htm|publisher=The City of Ausitn|accessdate=June 27, 2011}}</ref> The city council, including the mayor, are voted by Austin's residents. In 2014, Austin changed its at-large system of electing city council members to a 10-1 district-based system. The mayor serves a four-year term.
[[Austin Central Fire Station 1]], 2, and 4 of the [[Austin Fire Department]], all of which are located in downtown, provide fire protection.<ref name=afdmap>{{cite web|title=Austin Fire Department Station Map|url=http://www.ci.austin.tx.us/fire/afdmap.htm|publisher=The City of Austin|accessdate=June 27, 2011}}</ref>

==Arts and culture== [[Image:AMOA-Downtown.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Austin Museum of Art]] – Downtown]] Downtown Austin is famous for its culture and [[6th Street (Austin)|6th Street]], a historic street and entertainment district.<ref name=6thstreet>{{cite web|title=About Austin's 6th Street |url=http://www.6street.com/6s_pg_about.htm |publisher=About6street.com |accessdate=June 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623070132/http://www.6street.com/6s_pg_about.htm |archivedate=June 23, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
===Theaters===
[[Image:State Theater in Austin, TX IMG 6259.JPG|right|thumb|Located at 719 Congress Avenue near the capitol building, the State Theater was built in 1935; it was the first theater constructed specifically for the airing of films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/7453|title=State Theater|publisher=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=January 27, 2013}}</ref>]] The Paramount Theater is an Austin cultural icon.<ref name=paramount>{{cite web|title=The Paramount Theatre – History |url=http://www.austintheatre.org/site/PageNavigator/venues/paramount/history |publisher=Austin Theatre |accessdate=June 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726021338/http://www.austintheatre.org/site/PageNavigator/venues/paramount/history |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref> Built and completed in 1915, it was originally made for [[vaudeville]]. Over the years, as movies became the leading form of entertainment, the theater was remodeled with [[upholstered]] chairs and a [[state-of-the-art]] sound system.<ref name=paramount /> The theater would nearly close in the 1960s as people made the move from theaters to television.<ref name=paramount /> However, the building would be [[Building restoration|restored]] before closing, leading the Paramount Theater to avoid [[demolition]]. Today, the theater continues to operate, viewing popular movies.<ref name=paramount />
===Museums=== [[The Contemporary Austin]] Jones Center is located at 700 Congress Avenue. The Contemporary Austin is Austin, Texas's primary community art museum, consisting of two primary locations and an art school.

'''Downtown''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]], [[Virginia]], [[United States]]. Located geographically at the center of the city, Downtown began its development with the completion of the [[Shenandoah Valley Railroad (N&W)|Shenandoah Valley Railroad]] in 1882. Today the Downtown core is noted as the center of business for the [[Roanoke Valley]] and [[Southwest Virginia]], the [[Roanoke City Market Historic District|Roanoke City Market]], the [[Roanoke Downtown Historic District (Roanoke, Virginia)|Roanoke Downtown Historic District]] and many other attractions and amenities.<ref name="MarketContext">{{cite web |url=http://www.roanokeva.gov/85256A8D0062C8D5/vwFilesByName/CityMarketPlan/$File/HistoricContext.pdf |title=City Market District Plan: Historic Context |publisher=Duany Plater-Zyberk & Company |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref>
==Location== Geographically, downtown Roanoke is defined by the city as the area bound by [[Interstate 581]] on the east, 5th Street to the west, the [[Norfolk and Western]] railroad tracks to the north and Day Avenue to the south. This area is the location of the central core and the historic Market District. An additional section of downtown is located south of Day Avenue, bound to the east by the [[Roy L. Webber Expressway]], South Jefferson Street to the west and Albemarle Avenue to the south. This area is the location of the former [[Carilion Health System|Carilion]] Community Hospital and the [[Jefferson College of Health Sciences]].<ref name="DowntownMap">{{cite web |url=http://www.roanokeva.gov/85256A8D0062AF37/CurrentBaseLink/N25ZDPN6184FGUREN |title=Outlook Roanoke- The Downtown Area Plan |publisher=City of Roanoke Planning Division |accessdate=2008-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528152835/http://www.roanokeva.gov/85256A8D0062AF37/CurrentBaseLink/N25ZDPN6184FGUREN |archivedate=2010-05-28 |df= }}</ref>
Downtown borders the neighborhoods of the [[West End, Roanoke, Virginia|West End]] on the west, [[Belmont, Roanoke, Virginia|Belmont]] on the east, [[Gainsboro, Roanoke, Virginia|Gainsboro]] on the north and both [[Old Southwest, Roanoke, Virginia|Old Southwest]] and [[South Jefferson, Roanoke, Virginia|South Jefferson]] on the south.<ref name="DowntownMap2">{{cite web |url=http://portal.roanokegov.com/portal/neighbor/dspMapView.cfm?CFID=267835&CFTOKEN=18696877 |title=Explore Roanoke Neighborhood Map: Downtown |publisher=City of Roanoke Department of Neighborhoods |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref>
==History== The initial establishment of the [[Gainesborough, Virginia|Gainesborough]] in 1835 was located to the northeast of present-day downtown.<ref name="Gainsboro2">{{cite web |url=http://www.roanokeva.gov/85256A8D0062AF37/CurrentBaseLink/0477E02E1C815712852570D00070EC94/$File/gainsboro_plan_intro.pdf |title=Gainsboro Neighborhood Plan: History |publisher=City of Roanoke Planning Division |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref> The first structures constructed in what is now downtown occurred in the period following the completion of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad line in 1852 to the south of Gainesborough. Now known as Big Lick, during the period of [[Reconstruction era of the United States|reconstruction]] following the [[American Civil War]], the rail infrastructure was restored and the first municipal structure completed in present-day downtown was a jail.<ref name="NRHPnom1">{{cite web|last=Blanton|first=Allison Stone|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Roanoke Downtown Historic District District|url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/Cities/Roanoke/128-5761_Roanoke_Downtown_HD_2002_Final_Nomination.pdf|date=March 2002|accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref>
By 1881 the [[Shenandoah Valley Railroad (N&W)|Shenandoah Valley Railroad]] announced that Big Lick would be the southern terminus of its line resulting in the rapid growth and development of the community. With the arrival of the railroad, Big Lick would incorporate as the city of Roanoke in 1882.<ref name="NRHPnom1"/> The rapid growth resulted in the citizens passing a $90,000 bond in 1886 to provide for the infrastructure to support the growing community. With the adequate infrastructure in place, downtown would see a rapid expansion from the area around the present-day Campbell Avenue/Jefferson Street intersection outward.<ref name="NRHPnom1"/>
During the period between the wars, Downtown would continue to prosper and expand outwards. Many new structures were constructed in a variety of contemporary styles. Some of the notable structures completed during this period include the nine-story [[Boxley Building]] in 1921, the eleven-story [[Patrick Henry Hotel]] in 1925 and the twelve-story [[Colonial National Bank (Roanoke, Virginia)|Colonial National Bank]] in 1927, which stood as the city's tallest through the 1970s.<ref name="NRHPnom1"/> The downtown core would continue to see growth and prosperity through the period immediately following [[World War II]] and into the 1950s.<ref name="NRHPnom1"/>
With the opening of [[Crossroads Mall (Virginia)|Crossroads Mall]] in 1961, more shops would close their Downtown doors, with more people choosing to shop outside the city center.<ref name="AirportHistory">{{cite web |url=http://www.roanokeva.gov/85256A8D0062AF37/CurrentBaseLink/EC5B1D24CD75FD418525740A00621F11/$File/WRAP_Intro.pdf |title=Williamson Road Area Plan: Development History |publisher=City of Roanoke Planning Division |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref> Although declining as a retail destination, the 1970s saw a construction boom resulting in a reshaping of the skyline. Both the thirteen-story [[Crestar Bank]] Building (now the BB&T Bank Building) and the sixteen-story First National Exchange Bank Building (now the Carilion Administrative Services Building) were completed in 1973 and the fourteen-story Poff Federal Building was completed in 1976, with each still prominent features of the downtown cityscape.<ref name="Emporis">{{cite web |url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/ci/bu/sk/li/?id=102796&bt=2&ht=2&sro=1 |title=High-rise Buildings of Roanoke |publisher=Emporis |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref>
Established in 1882, the Roanoke City Market is the oldest continuously operating [[farmers market]] in the Commonwealth of Virginia and forms the central gathering place of the Downtown district.<ref name="MarketContext"/><ref name="Market">{{cite web |url=http://www.roanokefarmersmarket.com/ |title=Welcome to Roanoke Farmer's Market |publisher=Roanoke Farmer's Market |accessdate=2008-08-04}}</ref> By the 1960s the market would begin to decline, hitting its low point in the 1970s.<ref name="MarketContext"/> Seen as the key to the revitalization of Downtown, the ''Design 79'' plan was initiated to stimulate the revitalization and redevelopment of the market area. Through its and subsequent plans implementation, the market area was revitalized with the efforts now expanding outside the market area throughout Downtown.<ref name="MarketContext"/>
By the early 1990s Downtown would again be reshaped with the completion of both the 21-story Dominion Tower (now the Wells Fargo Tower) in 1991 as the city's tallest structure and the twelve-story Norfolk Southern Building in 1992.<ref name="Emporis"/> By the early 2000s (decade) downtown would experience the conversion of many former office buildings, stores and warehouses into residential living units.<ref name="Roanoker">{{cite web |url = http://www.theroanoker.com/favoritearticles/downtownliving_so06/index.cfm |title = Downtown Living: Its Time Has Come |publisher = The Roanoker |accessdate = 2008-08-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080703214539/http://www.theroanoker.com/favoritearticles/downtownliving_so06/index.cfm |archivedate = 2008-07-03 |df = }}</ref>
==Structures and districts on the National Register== [[Image:roanokefirestation1.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Fire Station #1: The Firehouse was in operation from 1907 through 2007.]] * [[Boxley Building]] * [[Campbell Avenue Complex]] * [[Colonial National Bank (Roanoke, Virginia)|Colonial National Bank]] * [[Fire Station No. 1 (Roanoke, Virginia)|Fire Station No. 1]] * [[First National Bank (Roanoke, Virginia)|First National Bank]] * [[Patrick Henry Hotel]] * [[Roanoke City Market Historic District]] * [[Roanoke Downtown Historic District (Roanoke, Virginia)|Roanoke Downtown Historic District]] * [[Roanoke Downtown Historic District (Roanoke, Virginia)|Roanoke Downtown Historic District (Boundary Increase)]] * [[Roanoke Warehouse Historic District]] * [[Salem Avenue-Roanoke Automotive Commercial Historic District]]
===Other notable places=== * [[Taubman Museum of Art]] * [[Center in the Square]] * [[Virginia Museum of Transportation]] * [[Wells Fargo Tower (Roanoke)|Wells Fargo Tower]]

{{notability|Companies|date=June 2014}} {{Primary sources|date=June 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox organisation | name = European Council for Distance Learning EUCDL | image = | caption = Emblem | formation = | type = non-profit organization | leader_title = | leader_name = | location = [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] | website = {{URL|www.eucdl.com}} }} The '''European Council for Distance Learning''' or '''EUCDL''' is a private non-profit organization registered under the EU law to help online and Distance Universities/schools to improve their know-how using the latest e-learning technologies and methods to ensure high quality.
==Goals== * Explore alternative teaching methods for students * Create special group activities that apply to more than one school * Entertain those willing to learn and think outside the box * Provide alternative measures for getting enrollment numbers high
==Partners== ''EUCDL'' has 4 partners: * [[European Council of Leading Business Schools]] or ECLBS * [[Graduates of BEST International Business Schools]] or GBIBS * [[International Board for Medical Research and Studies]] or IBMRS
==External links== * [http://www.eucdl.com/ Official website] * [http://eclbs.org/ European Council of Leading Business Schools] * [http://www.sapsu.org/ Swiss Association for Private Schools and Universities] * [http://www.gbibs.com/ Graduates of BEST International Business Schools] * [http://ibmrs.org International Board for Medical Research and Studies]

{{Infobox Organization |name = European Foundation for Management Development |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = EFMD |motto = Acting as a catalyst to promote and enhance excellence in management development internationally |formation = 1972<ref>{{cite journal |title=EFMD EUROPEAN FOUNDATION FOR MANAGEMENT DEVELOPMENT|url=http://www.asfor.it/aree-attivita/asfor-informa/item/247-efmd-european-foundation-for-management-development|journal=http://www.asfor.it|date = 17 January 2013}}</ref> |extinction = |type = Not-for-profit organization |status = |purpose = [[Educational accreditation]] |headquarters = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] |location = |region_served = Global |membership = over 800 in 80 countries |language = |leader_title = Chief Executive Officer |leader_name = Eric Cornuel |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.efmd.org/ www.efmd.org] |remarks = }}The '''European Foundation for Management Development''' ('''EFMD''') is an international not-for-profit association, based in Brussels, Belgium.<ref>{{cite journal |title=L'European Foundation for Management Development (EFMD)|url=http://www.groupeiam.com/index.php/accueil-efmd/72-international/organismes-internationaux-de-labellisation/100-l-european-foundation-for-management-development-efmd|journal=http://www.groupeiam.com}}</ref> Europe's largest network association in the field of management development,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mba-courses.com/efmd.htm |title=European Foundation for Management Development: EQUIS Accreditation: A Level of Quality |work=MBA Courses Worldwide |publisher=Sandringham Publishing Ltd |accessdate=August 19, 2010}}</ref> it has over 890 member organizations from [[academia]], business, public service and consultancy in 88 countries (as of September 2017). EFMD provides a forum for networking in [[management development]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=European Foundation for Management Development|url=http://10times.com/organizers/european-foundation-for-management-development-efmd|journal=http://10times.com}}</ref>
EFMD operates the '''EFMD Quality Improvement System''' ([[EFMD Quality Improvement System|EQUIS]]), which is one of the leading international systems of quality assessment, improvement, and accreditation of higher education institutions in management and business administration. It is comparable to its American equivalent [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] and provides a forum for information, research, networking and debate on innovation and best practice in management development.<ref>{{cite news |title= Hayleys case study by INSEAD wins top award in Europe |location=Sri Lanka |newspaper=[[The Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)|The Daily Mirror]] |date=3 June 2010 |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/print/index.php/business/127-local/12150.html |accessdate=August 19, 2010}}</ref>
The foundation also runs the EPAS accreditation system for programmes as well as the EFMD Deans Across Frontiers development programme (EDAF) and the Business School Impact System (BSIS).<ref>{{cite journal |title=European Foundation for Management Development (EFMD)|url=http://www.unprme.org/about-prme/governance/efmd.php|journal=http://www.unprme.org}}</ref>
== Types of accreditation ==
While the [[EQUIS]] accreditation process, which is valid for an entire school (or faculty), is the main type of accreditation EFMD offers, there are a variety of other accreditations available. With EPAS<ref>{{cite web |title= EPAS Accreditation EFMD Programme accreditation System (EPAS) |url=http://www.efmd.org/index.php/services-for-business-schools/epas-accreditation |accessdate=November 1, 2010}}</ref> it is possible for business schools to have certain degree programs accredited rather than the entire school. This variant somewhat resembles the AMBA ([[Association of MBAs]]) accreditation, as the London-based Association accredits the school's entire portfolio of [[MBA]] programs, but does not accredit the entire business school. EFMD also offers an accreditation for online courses (EOCCS) and for corporate learning (CLIP).
== Triple Accreditation ==
In business and management education, acquiring multiple accreditation by [[EQUIS]], [[AACSB]] and [[Association of MBAs|AMBA]] is often considered the "gold standard" because a business school must go to through a rigorous certification process by each of the three accreditation bodies. Schools that acquire all three are often referred to as having a [[Triple accreditation]] or Triple Crown accreditation.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Grandes écoles: les labels enfin décryptés|url=http://etudiant.aujourdhui.fr/etudiant/info/labels-accreditations-grandes-ecoles-enfin-decryptes.html|journal=http://etudiant.aujourdhui.fr|date = 13 March 2014}}</ref>
== EFMD activities ==
EFMD is the European partner in the [[China Europe International Business School]] ([[CEIBS]]), a joint venture with [[Shanghai Jiaotong University]] established as the first international business school with autonomous status in 1994 under an agreement between the [[European Commission]] and the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation.<ref>{{cite web |title= Global Initiatives |url=http://www.efmd.org/images/stories/efmd/downloadables/EFMD_About_EFMD_Update_2011_ONLINE.pdf |accessdate=May 24, 2012}}</ref> EFMD is also founding partner of the Global Foundation for Management Education (GFME), which is a joint venture with the US-based Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business ([[AACSB]] International).<ref>{{cite web |title= Global Initiatives |url=http://www.efmd.org/images/stories/efmd/downloadables/EFMD_About_EFMD_Update_2011_ONLINE.pdf |accessdate=May 24, 2012}}</ref> EFMD organizes conferences and seminars around the world for management development industry and published the [http://globalfocusmagazine.com Global Focus magazine].
In 2009, EFMD received an EU grant worth €2.2m<ref>{{cite web |title= 2009 Annual Action Programme for Non-State Actors and Local Authorities in Development |url=http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/documents/aap/2009/af_aap_2009_dci-nsa_p2.pdf |accessdate=November 1, 2010}}</ref> for a project that aims to improve the efficiency of Cuban companies by providing training to senior managers. This project, called '''Consolidating and Strengthening Cuban Managerial Capabilities''',<ref>{{cite web |title= Consolidating and Strengthening Cuban Managerial Capabilities |url=http://www.efmd.org/index.php/international-projects/current-projects/cuba-project |accessdate=November 1, 2010}}</ref> is to be implemented under the leadership of EFMD together with [[ESADE]], a business school in Barcelona, and the Cuban Ministry of Higher Education.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.efmd.org/ official website]

{{Infobox Union |name= ETUI |country= [[European Union]] |staff= 70 people |full_name= European Trade Union Institute |native_name= |image= [[File:Etui logo.jpg|175px]] |founded= 2005 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_int |office= [[Brussels]], Belgium |people= [[Philippe Pochet]], General Director,
Maria Jepsen, Director of the Research Department,
[[Ulisses Garrido]], Director of the Education Department |website= {{URL|www.etui.org}} |footnotes= }} The '''European Trade Union Institute''' (ETUI) is the independent research and training institute of the European Trade Union Confederation [[ETUC]]. The ETUI was formed in 2005, following a merger of three specialist bodies: the European Trade Union Institute (ETUI, founded in 1978), the European Trade Union College (ETUCO, founded in 1989) and the Trade Union Technical Bureau (TUTB, founded in 1989.{{cite book|last1=Degryse|first1=Christophe|title=1979-2013 40 years of history of the European Trade Union Confederation|date=2013|publisher=ETUI|isbn=978-2-87452-304-5|pages=251}} The ETUI is composed of two departments: * Research * Education The ETUI conducts studies and researches on macroeconomics and social policies in Europe, industrial relations and health and safety at work in Europe. It also delivers training to trade unionists belonging to National confederations and European Trade Union Federations across Europe on a wide range of topics. == Governance == The ETUI is a non-profit international association (AISBL) based in Brussels, Belgium. The Institute is composed of a General Assembly, which meets at least once a year and it is composed of members of the ETUC. It elects the members of the Management Committee. The Management Committee is composed of 28 members of the ETUC, elected by the General Assembly and it deals with the administration of the Institute. The Director's Committee is composed of: * Luca Visentini, General Secretary of the ETUC * Peter Scherrer, Deputy General Secretary of the ETUC (in charge of the ETUI) * Philippe Pochet, General Director ETUI * Maria Jepsen, Director of the Research Department * Ulisses Garrido, Director of the Education Department * Olga Barth, Administrative and Finance Manager{{cite web|url=http://www.etui.org/About-Etui/Governance|website=European Trade Union Institute|title=Governance}} An Advisory Group, composed of 25 members contributes to the multi-annual strategy of the ETUI.{{cite web|url=http://www.etui.org/About-Etui/Advisory-Group|website=European Trade Union Institute|title=Advisory Group}} == Research == The five priorities of the ETUI work programme are: * The crisis and the reinforced economic governance system * Worker participation and industrial relations * Sustainable development and industrial policy * Working condition and job quality * Trade Union Renewal{{cite web|title=Work Programme 2015-2016|url=http://www.etui.org/content/download/20232/165927/file/Work+programme+2015-2016.pdf|website=European Trade Union Institute|accessdate=12 April 2016}} The ETUI publishes several different publications aimed at different audiences, from policy makers, to practitioners and trade unionists. Every year the ETUI, in collaboration with the ETUC publishes [http://www.etui.org/Publications2/Books/Benchmarking-Working-Europe-2016 Benchmarking Working Europe], the ETUI’s annual stock-take of macro-economic, social and bargaining conditions in Europe.{{cite web|title=ETUI report underlines the costs of austerity|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/netuf/2014/04/07/etui-report-underlines-the-costs-of-austerity/#more-137|website=New European Trade Union Forum|accessdate=12 April 2016}} === Periodicals === * [[Transfer (journal)|Transfer]]: European Review of Labour and Research is a quarterly peer-reviewed academic journal that covers the field of management studies. It is published by [[SAGE Publications]] on behalf of the European Trade Union Institute. * [http://www.etui.org/Publications2/Periodicals/SEER-Journal-for-Labour-and-Social-Affairs-in-Eastern-Europe SEER Journal for Labour and Social Affairs in Eastern Europe]: SEER, the Journal for Labour and Social Affairs in Eastern Europe, is published for the European Trade Union Institute by Nomos, Germany.{{cite web|title=SEER|url=http://www.seer.nomos.de/|website=Nomos|accessdate=12 April 2016}} * [http://www.etui.org/Publications2/Periodicals/HesaMag HesaMag]: HesaMag is a magazine all about health and safety at work, published in English and French since 2009.{{cite news|title=HesaMag, un nouveau magazine sur la santé au travail en Europe et dans le monde|url=http://www.viva.presse.fr/HesaMag-un-nouveau-magazine-sur-la_13156.html|accessdate=12 April 2016|agency=Viva|date=22 December 2009}} == Education == Previously European Trade Union College, the Education department of the ETUI provides training and learning activities for trade unionists across Europe. It delivers about 100 courses a year to more than 2000 participants. Trade unionists members of the ETUC, or [http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=707&langId=en&intPageId=211 European Works' Councils], SE works council and special negotiation bodies (such as company level employee representatives) can participate to the training. Some of the courses lead to a qualification, in collaboration with [[Trades Union Congress|TUC]] in the UK and [[University of Lille]] in France. == Networks == * [https://www.etui.org/Networks/GoodCorp-the-research-network-on-Corporate-Governance GoodCorp - the research network on Corporate Governance] * [http://www.turi-network.eu/ Trade Union related Research Institutes (TURI)] * [http://seeurope.worker-participation.eu/ SEEurope - the research network on the European Company (SE)] * [https://www.etui.org/Networks/The-Transnational-Trade-Union-Rights-Experts-Network-TTUR The Transnational Trade Union Rights Experts Network (TTUR)] * [[Netlex - the ETUC network of trade union legal experts]] * [[Network on psychosocial risks]] * [[Eurotrainers]] * [[European Trade Union centres and schools]] == Services == * Web site [http://www.worker-participation.eu/ Worker Participation.eu] * [http://www.ewcdb.eu/ European Works Councils Database (EWCDB)] * [http://www.ewctraining.eu/ EWC Training.eu] * [http://ecdb.worker-participation.eu/ European Company (SE) Database] * [http://www.worker-participation.eu/EU-Social-Dialogue/Sectoral-ESD European sectoral social dialogue database] * [http://www.labourline.org/ The Documentation Centre] * [http://www.etui.org/Services/RISCTOX-database RISCTOX database] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.etui.org Official website of the European Trade Union Institute] * [http://www.labourline.org/ The Documentation Centre] * [http://www.worker-participation.eu/ Worker Participation.eu] * [http://www.ewcdb.eu/ European Works Councils Database (EWCDB)] * [http://www.ewctraining.eu/ EWC Training.eu] * [http://www.turi-network.eu/ Trade Union related Research Institutes (TURI)] [[Category:Labor relations]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:Think tanks based in Belgium]] [[Category:Research institutes in Belgium]]

[[File:Governance Institute of Australia logo.svg|thumb|Governance Institute of Australia logo]] '''Governance Institute of Australia''' (Governance Institute), formerly '''Chartered Secretaries Australia''', is an independent professional association for [[Company secretary|company secretaries]], governance advisers and risk managers in Australia, committed to promoting sound practice in [[governance]] and [[risk management]].
== History == {{unreferenced section|date=December 2014}} A number of company secretaries joined together in the United Kingdom in 1891 to form a society which promoted their professional interests. The society obtained incorporation under a Royal Charter in 1902 and the members of the Chartered Institute of Secretaries of Joint Stock Companies and other Public Bodies become known as Chartered Secretaries. An amendment to the Institute's Charter gave it the name of the [[Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators]] (ICSA) in 1971.
Established in Australia in 1909, the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators — Australian Division changed its name to Governance Institute of Australia in 2013.
== Profile == The Governance Institute independently advocates for reform in corporate governance.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Durkin | first = Patrick | title = Pay reforms unnecessary, say experts | pages = | newspaper = Australian Financial Review | location = Australia | date = 21 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | last = Potts | first = David | title = Cast your vote for a share of the action | newspaper = Sydney Morning Herald | location = Sydney | date = 30 August 2010 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/money/planning/cast-your-vote-for-a-share-of-the-action-20100830-140dz.html | accessdate = 1 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = CSA wants more share register protection | newspaper = Sydney Morning Herald | location = Sydney | date = 31 July 2009 | url = http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-business/csa-wants-more-share-register-protection-20090731-e4bk.html | accessdate = 1 March 2011}}</ref> and releases research on governance and risk management.<ref>{{Cite news |title=ASX500 falls down on risk management |newspaper=Risk Management Magazine |location=Australia |date=2 December 2010 |url=http://www.riskmanagementmagazine.com.au/articles/00/0C06E000.asp |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305001143/http://riskmanagementmagazine.com.au/articles/00/0c06e000.asp |archivedate=5 March 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The Governance Institute is a member of the [[Australian Securities Exchange]] (ASX) Corporate Governance Council,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Council Representatives |publisher=Australian Securities Exchange |url=http://www.asx.com.au/governance/corporate-governance-council-representatives.htm |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226150921/http://www.asx.com.au/governance/corporate-governance-council-representatives.htm |archivedate=26 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> which issues the Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations against which all Australian listed companies must report. The Governance Institute regularly publishes Good Governance Guides which focus on the practical aspects of implementing sound practice in governance and corporate law.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Good Governance Guides | publisher = Governance Institute of Australia | url = https://www.governanceinstitute.com.au/knowledge-resources/guidance-tools/good-governance-guides/ | accessdate = 5 May 2017}}</ref>
The Governance Institute also publishes a journal<ref>{{Cite web | title = Register of Refereed Journals | publisher = Australian Government, Department of Education, Science and Training | date = 3 February 2006 | url = http://mams.rmit.edu.au/e6a5p0uq0ei8.pdf | accessdate = 5 May 2017}}</ref> and a publications program, and offers public and in-house training, conferences and education in governance and risk management.
== Education ==
The Governance Institute provides internationally recognised qualifications in the areas of governance and risk management and provides training to organisations to help them with their governance practices.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Chartered Secretaries Tackle NFP Governance | publisher = Pro Bono News | date = 11 August 2010 | url = http://www.probonoaustralia.com.au/news/2010/08/chartered-secretaries-tackle-nfp-governance | accessdate = 1 March 2011}}</ref>
The Governance Institute's Graduate Diploma of Applied Corporate Governance is the only applied postgraduate course in governance with higher education accreditation in Australia.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Those with accountability responsibilities or who have oversight of implementing governance frameworks in either the private or public sectors can undertake the course. The Governance Institute Associate and Fellow Members are entitled to use the postnominals AGIA and FGIA, as well as the designation Chartered Secretary and the postnominals ACIS and FCIS.<ref>{{Cite web | title = The Right Membership For You | publisher = Governance Institute of Australia | url = https://www.governanceinstitute.com.au/membership/the-right-membership-for-you/ | accessdate = 5 May 2017}}</ref>
In addition, Governance Institute offers two risk specific postgraduate courses: Graduate Certificate of Applied Risk Management and Graduate Diploma of Applied Risk Management and Corporate Governance. These courses are intended for risk management practitioners and senior managers with responsibility for risk management and corporate governance functions. It is also highly relevant for governance practitioners seeking to broaden their risk management skills.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Postgraduate Risk Courses | publisher = Governance Institute of Australia | url = http://www.governanceinstitute.com.au/learning/postgraduate-courses/graduate-certificate-of-applied-risk-management/ | accessdate = 16 December 2014}}</ref>
Further to this, Governance Institute offers both a Certificate in Governance Practice and a Certificate in Governance and Risk Management that provides qualifications and vocational governance and risk management training. The Governance Institute Certificated Members carry the nationally recognised post nominal of GIA(Cert).<ref>{{Cite web | title = Short Courses & Certificates | publisher = Governance Institute of Australia | url = https://www.governanceinstitute.com.au/education-training/short-courses-certificates/ | accessdate = 5 May 2017}}</ref>

{{Other people|Henry Tucker}} {{Infobox Prime Minister | honorific-prefix = | name = Henry Tucker | honorific-suffix =[[Member of Parliament|MP]] | image = | order = 1st [[Premier of Bermuda|Government Leader of Bermuda]] | term_start = 10 June 1968 | term_end = 29 December 1971 |monarch = [[Elizabeth II]] | governor = [[Roland Robinson, 1st Baron Martonmere|Roland Robinson]] | predecessor = New office | successor =[[Edward Richards]] | birth_date = 14 March 1903 | birth_place = [[Image:Flag of Bermuda.svg|25px]] {{spaces|3}}[[Bermuda]] | death_date = | death_place = | constituency = | party = [[United Bermuda Party]] | spouse = Catherine Tucker | religion = Roman Catholic}}
'''Sir Henry James "Jack" Tucker''' (14 March 1903 – 9 January 1986) was the first [[Premiers of Bermuda|Government Leader]] of [[Bermuda]].<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Sir Henry Tucker Dies at 82; Was First Leader of Bermuda |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE6DD173FF932A25752C0A960948260&sec=&spon= |work= [[Reuters]] |publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=1986-01-11 |accessdate=2008-01-26}}</ref> He is considered — together with Dr. [[E. F. Gordon]] (1895 – 1955) - one of the island's two most important leaders of the 20th century.<ref name=Gazette>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110616/ISLAND11/706149916/-1 "Sir Henry Tucker - one of the Island's two most important leaders of the 20th Century", ''Royal Gazette'', 16 June 2011.]</ref><ref>[http://bermudabiographies.bm/Bios/bio-HenryTucker.html Bermuda Biographies.]</ref> Tucker first took office on 10 June 1968 and served until 29 December 1971, as a member of the [[United Bermuda Party]] (UBP), the [[political party]] that he helped found in 1964.<ref name=nyt/>
==Early life== Henry Tucker was born in Bermuda on 14 March 1903, the son of merchant Henry James and Nella Louise (born Trott).<ref name=nyt/> He was a direct descendant of the first British settlers in Bermuda, who included Daniel Tucker, an early [[Governor of Bermuda|Bermudian colonial governor]] in 1616.<ref name=nyt/> Bermuda's Trott family descend from famous 17th Century settler [[Perient Trott]] (1614-1679), who led the campaign against the [[Somers Isles Company]] that would lead to its dissolution in 1684.
Tucker was educated at [[Whitney Institute Middle School|Whitney Institute]] and at [[Saltus Grammar School]] in [[Hamilton, Bermuda|Hamilton]], before being sent at the age of 17, in 1920, to boarding school in [[England]], where he attended [[Sherborne School]] in [[Dorset]]. Lacking the means to pursue university studies, he returned to Bermuda in 1922 to find work.<ref name=Gazette/>
Tucker moved to [[New York City]], where from 1924 until 1934 he worked for several [[bank]]s and [[brokerage firm|stock brokerages]].<ref name=nyt/> Returning to Bermuda, he became an employee of the [[Bank of Bermuda]]. He was promoted to general manager in 1938.<ref name=nyt/> On his retirement in 1969 he was elected Deputy Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Bank of Bermuda, and would serve in this capacity until 1985.<ref name=Bank>[http://bermudascholarships.com/donor/Bank-of-Bermuda-Foundation/9 Bank Of Bermuda Foundation Sir Henry Tucker University Scholarship], bermudascholarships.com; accessed 19 June 2015.</ref>
==Politics== In 1938 Tucker was elected to Parliament as a representative in [[Paget Parish|Paget]].<ref name=Gazette/> Tucker was elected to the [[Bermuda House of Assembly]] in the 1950s. He helped found the United Bermuda Party in 1964, after spending almost 20 years in the Assembly.<ref name=nyt/> He immediately became the UBP's leader. Tucker became Bermuda's first Premier in 1968, after the island's first election with [[universal suffrage]].<ref name=nyt/>
Tucker resigned from office in 1971, citing his advancing age.<ref name=nyt/> He was [[knight]]ed by [[Queen Elizabeth II]] in 1972.<ref name=nyt/>
Famous quote:
{{quote|A man without a conflict of interests is a man without any interests|Sir Henry Tucker, founder of the Bermuda Trust Company (attr)<ref>Roger Crombie, ''Conyers, Dill & Pearman: A History'', The Walsingham Press, Bermuda, 1998, p. 54.</ref>}}
==Death== Sir Henry Tucker died in Bermuda on 9 January 1986 at the age of 82. He is survived by two of his children, Robert Newbold Tucker, who currently lives in Bermuda, and daughter Judy Denney, who currently lives in Texas.<ref name=nyt/>
==Legacy== *On Bermuda's National Heroes Day in June 2011, Sir Henry Tucker was honoured as one of the architects of modern Bermuda.<ref>[http://bernews.com/2011/04/three-new-national-heroes-to-be-honoured/ "Three New National Heroes To Be Honoured", BerNews, 28 April 2011.]</ref><ref>[http://onebda.com/opinion/49-new-national-heroes Jonathan Bell, "UBP salutes new national heroes", One BDA.]</ref><ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/section/island11 Bermuda's National Heroes, 16 June 2011.]</ref> *The Bank of Bermuda Foundation offers "Sir Henry Tucker University Scholarship and Education Grants" to help ensure the future of the island's youth.<ref name=Bank />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.bermudabiographies.bm/Bios/bio-HenryTucker.html Bermuda Biographies: Sir Henry James "Jack" Tucker] *[http://www.onebda.com/the-ubp-story The UBP Story, Sir Henry Tucker, United Bermuda Party website.]
{{Authority control}}

The '''Hindenburg Cup''' ({{lang-de|Hindenburg-Pokal}}) was a German aviation prize, founded in 1928 and awarded annually by [[President of Germany (1919–1945)|President]] and [[Field Marshal (Germany)|Field Marshal]] [[Paul von Hindenburg]] to recognize achievements in powered flight. From 1930 an additional prize was also awarded for [[gliding]].
==Winners== * 1928 : [[Friedrich Karl von Koenig-Warthausen]], for his flight from [[Berlin]] to [[Tehran]] * 1929 : [[Wolf Hirth]], for various European flights and his flight to [[Iceland]] * 1930 Powered flight : [[Henry Schlerf]], for volunteer training activities * 1930 Gliding : [[Robert Kronfeld]], for his achievements at the 10th Rhön competition * 1931 Powered flight : [[August Lauw]], for his flight from [[Wilhelmshaven]] to [[Alexandria]] * 1931 Gliding : [[Günther Groenhoff]], for his success with the high-performance glider ''Fafnir'' * 1932 Powered flight : [[Elly Beinhorn]], for her flights from Germany to Africa in 1931 and to Australia in 1932 * 1932 Gliding : [[Wolf Hirth]], for his achievements in research and [[thermal]] flight * 1933 Powered flight : [[Charles Schwabe]], for his flight from [[Böblingen]] to [[Cape Town]] * 1933 Gliding : [[Peter Riedel]], for his "great flying performance" and observations of thermal updrafts * 1934 Powered flight : No trophy awarded * 1934 Gliding : [[Heini Dittmar]], for setting altitude and long-distance records
After the death of Hindenburg in 1934 the Hindenburg Cup was renamed the Adolf Hitler Prize (''Adolf-Hitler-Preis'').
==References== * {{cite book |last1=Anders |first1=Karl |last2=Eichelbaum |first2=Hans |title=Wörterbuch des Flugwesens |trans-title=Dictionary of Aviation |date=1937 |publisher=Quelle und Meyer |location=[[Leipzig]] |language=German}} * {{cite book |last1=Supf |first1=Peter |title=Das Buch der deutschen Fluggeschichte |trans-title=The Book of German Aviation History |volume=2 |date=1935 |publisher=Klemm |location=Berlin-Grunewald |language=German }} * {{cite book |last1=Brütting |first1=Peter |title= Das Buch der deutschen Fluggeschichte |trans-title=The Book of German Aviation History |volume=3 |date=1979 |publisher= Drei-Brunnen-Verlag |location=Stuttgart |language=German |isbn= 3-87174-001-2}}

{{multiple issues|{{advert|date=May 2012}}{{refimprove|date=May 2012}}}} '''Horst M. Rechelbacher''' (1941 – February 15, 2014) was an [[ Austrian American]] businessman, who was the founder of the cosmetics company [[Aveda|Aveda Corporation]] and Intelligent Nutrients. His interest in developing products without toxic chemicals launched the market for natural cosmetics in the United States.<ref name=Vitello />
==Early life== Rechelbacher was born in [[Klagenfurt]], [[Austria]] to an herbalist and shoe maker/designer and was the youngest of three brothers. His family apartment overlooked a small salon across the street in central Klagenfurt. During his childhood, Rechelbacher had many opportunities to observe the daily activities of the salon. He was both intrigued and inspired by the salon and when the time came to choose a vocation or continue with a formal education, he chose the salon profession. At age fourteen, he embarked on a three-year apprenticeship in the beauty and salon industry. During his apprenticeship, he was a three-time winner of the Austrian Junior Championships. At seventeen, he moved to [[Italy]] and started work at an exclusive salon in [[Rome]].
==India and Ayurvedic Influences== In 1970, Rechelbacher went to Florida to participate in a number of different competitions. During those he became sick due to the products he was using on clients' hair and came up with the idea to start "Aveda" - an all natural hair products line.
Rechelbacher developed Clove Shampoo and later Cherry Almond Bark Conditioner based on his earlier renditions.
In 1978, he founded Aveda and began to expand the product line into hair, skin and body care, makeup, plant-based purefumes, (aromatherapy) and lifestyle products that were all centered on his newfound convictions.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} Under his guidance he continued a search for flower and plant ingredients around the globe and focused on working with indigenous peoples in mutually beneficial circumstances.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
Following the [[Exxon Valdez oil spill]], Rechelbacher was the first to sign onto the Valdez Principles, now the [[Ceres (organization)|Ceres]] principles, joining corporate environmental responsibility with corporate bottom line. In 1992, along with his partner Kiran, he attended the [[Earth Summit]], where three key agreements occurred: the Climate Change Convention, a precursor to the Kyoto Protocol, the [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] and an Intellectual Property Rights accord for indigenous peoples that included preventing actions that could be deemed culturally inappropriate and/or cause environmental destruction. Through this convention, Rechelbacher forged a relationship with the Brazilian [[Yawanawa]] tribe began a project cultivating uruku and replanting seedlings in deforested areas.
Nearly two decades after Rechelbacher incorporated, he sold Aveda to the [[Estee Lauder Companies]] but remained a consultant until March 2003.
==Intelligent Nutrients== In the years following the sale of Aveda, Horst became increasingly aware that the beauty industry was stagnating in the face increasing environmental degradation. In addition, new technologies that could better serve the consumer were being underutilized. Rechelbacher's fierce determination to improve the caliber of cosmetic products manifested itself in his latest company [http://www.intelligentnutrients.com Intelligent Nutrients]. IN is a certified organic, food-grade, non-toxic plant-based hair, skin, body, aroma and lifestyle company with the primary emphasis on using organically grown ingredients. The IN hair, skin and aromatherapy lines are notable for the USDA Certified Organic seal. Based on nutraceuticals, non-toxics and certified organic food ingredients and flavors, IN also uses post-consumer recycled packaging.
Later, Rechelbacher was a strong advocate within the cosmetic industry against “greenwashing” - misleading marketing claims and so-called organic companies who use the claim "organic" without certification - by bringing transparency and truth to beauty and cosmetic labeling.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
[http://www.horstandfriends.com Horst & Friends] (horstandfriends.com), an Intelligent Nutrients Certified Organic Salon, opened in June 2010 in the [http://www.intelligentnutrients.com Intelligent Nutrients] headquarters in Minneapolis.
==Projects== Rechelbacher was the founder and chairman of the Horst M. Rechelbacher Foundation, a philanthropic organization dedicated to social and environmental preservation projects that operate on a grass-roots level. His sustainable ideals and values are perpetuated through profit and non-profit organizations. He also owned HMR Galleries, an art and antiques business, and was involved in producing films including the 1999 film ''Hidden Medicine.''{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
[https://web.archive.org/web/20060911205033/http://www.oneroof.org/naha/modernlegends.html]
==Personal life== Rechelbacher maintained residences in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] and [[New York City]]. As well as a private estate and a company retreat, the Osceola, Wisconsin, property serves as an organic farm cultivating flowers and plants while also operating a distillery for the IN products. The farm and home are solar powered.
Rechelbacher was divorced with two children, a son Peter and a daughter Nicole. Nicole is a married mother of three, and former accessories and clothing designer for Aveda. Peter is married with a son, and provided expertise in finance, and was president of Intelligent Nutrients while at Aveda.
Horst lived and worked with his long-time companion, wife,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.minnesotamonthly.com/media/Minnesota-Monthly/July-2014/Style-Profile-Kiran-Stordalen/|date=July 2014|title=Style Profile: Kiran Stordalen|author=Schneider, Karen S.|publisher=Greenspring Media|journal=Minnesota Monthly|accessdate=January 3, 2015}}</ref> and former vice president of marketing and creative for Aveda, [[Kiran Stordalen]].
Rechelbacher died from complications of [[pancreatic cancer]] on February 15, 2014, at the age of 72 at his home in [[Osceola, Wisconsin]].<ref name=Vitello>{{cite news|title=Horst Rechelbacher, ‘Father of Safe Cosmetics,’ Dies at 72|author=Vitello, Paul|date=February 22, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/23/business/horst-rechelbacher-father-of-safe-cosmetics-dies-at-72.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=January 3, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Horst Rechelbacher Dies at 72">{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/beauty-industry-news/people/horst-rechelbacher-dies-at-72-7464020?src=nl/mornReport/20140218 | title=Horst Rechelbacher Dies at 72 | publisher=WWD | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014 | author=Julie Naughton and Pete Born with contributions from Belisa Silva}}</ref>
==Books== * ''Rejuvenation: a wellness guide for women and men''. Published 1987, Harper & Row. ({{ISBN|0-7225-1072-1}}) * ''Aveda Rituals: a daily guide to natural health and beauty''. Published 1999, Henry Holt. ({{ISBN|0-8050-5800-1}}) * ''Minding Your Business: Profits that Restore The Planet''. Published 2008, Earth Aware Editions. ({{ISBN|1601090129}}) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060504111113/http://intelligentnutrients.com/products/ProductDetails.aspx?productID=100&IsProductGroup=0 ''Alivelihood: The Art of Sustainable Success''.] Published 2006, HMR Publishing. ({{ISBN|0-9772677-0-9}})
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070106202533/http://www.intelligentnutrients.com/aboutus/our-founder.aspx Intelligent Nutrients: Our Founder] (Intelligent Nutrients website.) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060506084611/http://www.intelligentnutrients.com/community/2005_04_01_archive.htm A Sneak Preview at Horst's New Book - The Business of Being] (Intelligent Nutrients website.) * [http://www.horstgalleries.com/horst.aspx "Horst"] (Horst Galleries website.) * "Beauty and the Feast," by Mary Tannen. ''New York Times Magazine'', September 15, 2002, page 109. * "Super Natural," by Mark Sevjar. ''American Salon'', October 2005, page 110. * "Labors of Love," by Julie Sinclair. ''American Spa'', April 2005, page 26. * "Reputations: Dowry of earthly harmony," by Sarah Ryle. ''The Guardian'', November 22, 1997. City Page section, page 24. * "Aveda shops dabble in earthly delights," by Linda Gillian Griffin. ''Houston Chronicle'', August 29, 1996, Fashion section, page 2. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061009150057/http://www.enlightenedbrand.com/pages/ebj_2004-4.php The Natural Beauty of Aveda: A Discussion with Chris Hacker] ''Enlightened Brand Journal'', Autumn 2004. (Explanation of company name.) * "Go, earth girl!" ''Teen Magazine'' November 1995, page 84. (Story about Nicole Rechelbacher.)
{{reflist}}

{{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_size = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | status = active | genre = multidisciplinary alternative-porn festival | date = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} "dates=" also works, but do not use both --> | begins = 2012 | ends = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} --> | frequency = annually | venue =Les Docks, Le Bourg, Théâtre Arsenic, Théâtre Sévelin 36, Forma Art Contemportain, Librairie HumuS, Pully CityClub | location =[[Lausanne, Switzerland]] | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | country =[[Switzerland]] | years_active = 4 | first = 2012 | founder_name = <!-- or | founders = --> Viviane & Stéphane Morey | last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | capacity = | area = | budget = | activity = | leader_name = | patron = | organised = <!-- "organized=" also works --> | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = <!-- | or sponsors = --> | website = www.lafeteduslip.ch | footnotes = }}
'''La Fête du Slip''' (literally "''Panties Fest''" or "''Underpants Fest''") is an annual [[alternative porn|alternative-porn]] [[film festival]] held in [[Lausanne, Switzerland]]. It is [[Romandy]]'s first and biggest multidisciplinary festival whose sole purpose is to focus on body, [[Gender studies|gender]], and [[Sexuality portal|sexuality]] in [[art]]. It takes places during the first week-end of March since 2012.<ref name="360d">{{cite web | url=http://360.ch/blog/magazine/2015/03/fete-du-slip-les-sexualites-sexposent-positivement/ | title=Fête du slip: les sexualités s’exposent positivement | publisher=[[360°]] | date=6 March 2015 | accessdate=30 March 2016 | language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lemag.wyylde.com/cest-la-fete-du-slip-avec-viviane-morey/|title=C'est la Fête du slip avec Viviane Morey - Wyylde le Mag|website=Wyylde le Mag|language=fr-FR|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tracks.arte.tv/fr/le-slip-ca-se-fete|title=Le Slip, ça se fête ! {{!}} Tracks ARTE|website=Tracks {{!}} ARTE|language=fr-FR|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
== Description == La Fête du Slip is a festival celebrating diversity in bodies, gender and sexuality. It offers a select and diverse program of cinema, music, visual and performing arts, literature, and porn.
La Fête du Slip looks for contemporary emerging art. Its programming evolves around innovative and subversive works. Artistic projects transcending categories and proposing new forms of experimentation are favored.
By bringing together very different artworks that have an echo in their content, the festival aims at enriching the experience of its audience by creating unexpected encounters between artists.
== History and background ==
=== Edition 0 === Took place on the 9th of March 2012. 2 venues, 4 events, 4 artists, 675 in attendance.
=== 1st Edition === Took place between the 8th and 10 March 2013. 4 venues, 28 events, 32 artists, 1'840 in attendance.
=== 2nd Edition === Took place between the 6th and the 9th of March 2014. 5 venues, 30 events, 42 artists, 1'870 in attendance.
=== 3nd Edition === Took place between the 6th and the 8th of March 2015.<ref name="360d"/> 6 venues, 40 events, 46 artists, 2'800 in attendance.
=== 4th Edition === Took place between the 4th and the 6th of March 2016. 7 venues, 63 events, 75 artists, 3'400 in attendance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brain-magazine.fr/article/reportages/28690-Fete-du-Slip-de-Lausanne-sperme-et-cyprine-sur-le-tapis-rouge|title=Fête du Slip de Lausanne : sperme et cyprine sur le tapis rouge|website=www.brain-magazine.fr|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
== Hosting == La Fête du Slip takes place in seven venues in Lausanne: theaters, nightclubs, galleries, cinema...
== Les Préliminaires == Each edition gets an early kick-start with a party called Les Préliminaires (literally "The Foreplays") that takes place one week before the actual beginning of the festival. The main goal of this event was – and, to some extent, still is – to raise sufficient funds for the festival. However, having considerably grown in size and larger funds being involved and needed way ahead of time, this party's function is far more less the one of a fund raiser. It is now mostly a way for the festival enthusiasts to take a first pulse of the upcoming events and to discover the program in details.
== Audience == The audience of '''La Fête du Slip''' is very diverse. The variety of the program and the venues creates a unique blend, ranging from [[Queercore|queer punks]] to old literature enthusiasts, dance specialists, and [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipsters]]. With its thematic color, '''La Fête du Slip''' attracts many sub-cultures, like the [[LGBT]] community, the [[BDSM]]/kink/fetish community, [[Feminist movements and ideologies|feminist]] activists, pornographers, sex workers, or [[gender studies]] researchers. Most of its audience is local, but the festival attracts a growing number of international festival-goers each year. As a [[Paris Match|Paris-Match]] article put it in 2015: "Switzerland was famous for its banks and chocolates, and now it has been shining with its own porn festival for three years."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Spectacles/Le-festival-du-porno-intello-721592|title=La fête du Slip en Suisse - "Le festival du porno intello"|website=www.parismatch.com|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
== Le Slip d'Or == Since 2015, La Fête du Slip hosts an International Sex Positive Porn Competition called Le Slip d'Or, whose aim is to promote and reward the best of the burgeoning sex positive porn scene internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.letagparfait.com/fr/2015/09/14/la-competition-internationale-pour-le-slip-dor-2016-est-officiellement-lancee/|title=La compétition internationale pour le Slip d’Or 2016 est officiellement lancée|website=www.letagparfait.com|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
=== Spirit of the Competition ===
As Annie Sprinkle puts it: "The answer to bad porn isn't no porn... It's to try and make better porn!<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-4WICwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA170&ots=x9NUYKLk7a&dq=%2522The%2520answer%2520to%2520bad%2520porn%2520isn%2520't%2520no%2520porn%2520...it's%2520to%2520try%2520and%2520make%2520better%2520porn%2522&pg=PA170#v=onepage&q=%2522The%2520answer%2520to%2520bad%2520porn%2520isn%2520't%2520no%2520porn%2520...it's%2520to%2520try%2520and%2520make%2520better%2520porn%2522&f=false|title=The Pornography Industry: What Everyone Needs to Know|last=Tarrant|first=Shira|date=2016-03-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190205133|language=en}}</ref>". By acknowledging that a better, more subversive, empowering and liberated porn is being made, La Fête du Slip’s International Sex Positive Porn Competition brings together the porn performers, producers, distributors and consumers and makes this new cultural sector thrive.
By way of appeal for submission, worldwide pornographers are invited to send their sex positive porn films. A jury made of respected and well-known professionals then selects the ones that, according to them, are the more representative of a fresh and bold porn, while still remaining significantly marginal, and while authentically and humorously questioning the various definitions of pornography, sex, and gender. Among these selected films, ten are further nominated for the grand prize: '''Le Slip d’Or'''.
=== Structure, Criteria, Prizes ===
La Fête du Slip’s International Sex Positive Porn Competition has three concentric sections, with three prizes : * ''Le Fap d’Or'' This competitive section is open to all sex positive porn films, regardless of year of production, premiere status and duration. The films selected in the two more selective sections, Le Prix du Public and the ''Slip d’Or'' are included in this section automatically. Only the accredited professionals of the festival may vote for their favorite film, and the winner will receive the ''Fap d’Or'' prize. * ''Le Prix du Public'' This competitive section is limited to films of duration of less than 20 min, released in the 12 months prior to the submission deadline. Premiere status is not relevant. The audience of the festival will vote for their favorite film by paper ballot. The winner will win the ''Prix du Public'' prize. * The Official Competition - ''Le Slip d’Or'' A smaller selection of films will be in the official competition. A jury of three porn film professionals will judge these films. This competitive section is limited to films shorter than 20 minutes, released in the 12 months prior to the submission deadline, and films presenting at least their international premiere at La Fête du Slip, and Swiss premiere for Swiss films. The winner selected by the jury will receive the ''Slip d’Or'' prize
