{{Chinese name|[[Cai (surname)|Tsai]]}} '''Tsai Wan-lin''' ({{zh|c=蔡萬霖|p=Caì Wànlín}}; 10 November 1924 – 27 September 2004) was a Taiwanese businessman who, at the peak of his wealth in 1996, was considered to be the fifth richest person in the world,<ref>{{cite news|title=The billionaires' list|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19960701&id=TekyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xwcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6963,103314|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The Free Lance-Star]]|publisher=Google News|date=July 1, 1996}}</ref> with a family net worth of [[United States Dollar|US$]]12.2 billion.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bill Gates still richest, but Asian tycoons getting closer|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19960701&id=NCpdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=51oNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1782,97999|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Observer-Reporter]]|publisher=Google News|date=1 July 1996}}</ref> At the time of his death in 2004, he was the richest man in Taiwan with a fortune of US$4.6 billion ([[New Taiwan dollar|NT$]]156.3 billion), ranked 94th worldwide.<ref>{{cite news|title=PASSINGS Tsai Wan-lin, 80; Tycoon Was the Wealthiest Man in Taiwan|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/sep/29/local/me-passings29.1|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=29 September 2004}}</ref> He founded the [[Lin Yuan Group]], a large [[banking]] and [[insurance]] group.<ref>{{cite news|title=Who will replace Tsai Wan-lin as Taiwan's wealthiest person?|url=http://www.cens.com/cens/html/en/news/news_inner_6317.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|agency=China Economic News Service|date=29 September 2004}}</ref>
He was born into a poor [[farmer]]'s family in Chikunan Town, Chikunan District, [[Shinchiku Prefecture]], [[Taiwan under Japanese rule|Japanese-era Taiwan]] (modern-day [[Zhunan, Miaoli]]). Tsai started out in [[Taipei]] by selling vegetables and soybeans with his brothers as a child.<ref name=TaiTimes>{{cite news|last1=Lin|first1=Jackie|last2=Chen|first2=Kevin|title=Tsai led family to dominate nation's finance business|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/biz/archives/2004/09/29/2003204864|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Taipei Times]]|date=29 September 2004}}</ref>
With one of his brothers Tsai joined Taipei's Tenth Credit Cooperative in 1960.<ref name=Cpost>{{cite news|title=Tsai family may face huge heritage tax burden|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/business/asia/2004/09/29/52837/Tsai-family.htm|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[China Post]]|date=29 September 2004}}</ref> Two years later, they founded [[Cathay Life Insurance]], which at the time of his death was the largest life insurance company in Taiwan.<ref name=TaiTimes/> Tenth Credit Cooperative was eventually transferred to Tsai Wan-lin's nephew [[Tsai Chen-chou]].
The family split Cathay Life Insurance in 1979. Tsai Wan-lin founded the Lin Yuan Group with his share.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tsai Wan-lin, the Richest Man in Taiwan, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/29/business/worldbusiness/29tsai.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[New York Times]]|date=29 September 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Flannery |first1=Russell |title=Orderly Succession Is Seen at Lin-Yuan As Billionaire Wan-Lin Tsai Falls Ill |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB910041325366497500 |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=3 November 1998}}</ref> Over the next 10 years, the Lin Yuan Group expanded to become the largest Taiwanese conglomerate. [[Cathay Financial Holdings]], a division of the Lin Yuan Group, became Taiwan's largest financial holding company.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tsai Wan-lin|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-10-02/news/0410020212_1_tsai-wan-lin-taiwan-richest|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=29 September 2004}}</ref> Cathay Insurance was renamed Fubon Insurance in 1992.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flannery|first1=Russell|title=Citigroup's Secret Weapons|url=https://www.forbes.com/global/2001/0528/052.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=Forbes|date=28 May 2001}}</ref>
Tsai was first listed by Forbes as a billionaire in 1987.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flannery|first1=Russell|title=Oh, Brother|url=https://www.forbes.com/global/2001/0528/052.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Forbes]]|date=3 July 2009}}</ref> He was appointed a senior adviser to the [[president of the Republic of China]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nation's richest man dies at 79 after long illness|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2004/09/29/2003204803|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=Taipei Times|date=29 September 2004}}</ref>
He died of heart disease at the age of 81 in [[Taipei]]'s [[Cathay General Hospital]], which he founded in 1977. He had been hospitalized for six years.<ref name=Cpost/><ref>{{cite news |title=Taiwan's top billionaire dies at 81 |url=https://www.upi.com/Taiwans-top-billionaire-dies-at-81/68121096439352/ |accessdate=10 September 2018 |agency=United Press Internatoinal |date=29 September 2004}}</ref> Tsai was married to Chou Pao-chin and had seven children.<ref name=tele>{{cite news|title=Tsai Wan-lin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1474058/Tsai-Wan-lin.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=14 October 2004}}</ref>

[[File:Kekkonen-Raade-1961.jpg|thumb|right|Uolevi Raade (standing to the left) with [[Urho Kekkonen]] (sitting) in 1961.]] '''Tauno Uolevi Raade''' (5 July 1912 – 13 May 1998) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] industrialist and a long-time [[managing director]] of [[Neste Oil|Neste]] (now ''Neste Oil''), the Finnish national [[oil refining]] company.
Raade was born in [[Turku]], and received university degrees from [[Helsinki University of Technology]] (TKK) and [[Åbo Akademi]]. At TKK, he was one of the founders of the [[Polyteknikkojen Ilmailukerho|student flying club]]. During the Second World War he initially served as a fighter pilot, but was soon transferred into the industry. In 1945, he was appointed the director of Ministry of Trade and Industry, where he planned the payment of war reparations stipulated by the Soviet Union.
Already in this role he was involved in the founding of the Finnish oil industry. In 1955, he was appointed managing director of Neste. The first oil refinery at [[Naantali]] was brought on stream a couple of years after this. Raade and his friend, Prime Minister and from 1956 President of the Republic [[Urho Kekkonen]] were responsible for promoting the project; Kekkonen rallied the politicians and Raade took care of relations to industry at home and abroad.
In 1959, Raade also became the chairman of the company's board. He acted in both positions until his retirement in 1979. In addition to this post, he was also active in industrial federations and committees and was a member or chairman of the board of 37 corporations. He received the honorary title of [[vuorineuvos]] (the highest one awarded to industrialists) in 1962.
The former [[Fortum head office|headquarters building]] of [[Neste]], now occupied by [[Fortum]], is colloquially called ''Raateen hammas'' ‘Raade’s tooth’. It was constructed 1973–78 and is still the tallest office building in Finland.
==References== *[http://www.mtv3.fi/uutiset/arkisto/9805/980514/9805140149.html Obituary for Uolevi Raade] at [[MTV3]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Adewale Aladejana | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Adewale Opeyemi Aladejana | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|5|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Ibadan]], [[Oyo State|Oyo]], Nigeria | residence = Abuja, Nigeria | nationality = Nigerian | other_names = | citizenship = Nigerian (1984–present) | education = | alma_mater = [[Bowen University]] | occupation = Entrepreneur, Perfumer }}
'''Wale Aladejana''' (born May 16, 1984 in [[Ibadan]], [[Oyo State]]) is a Nigerian Entrepreneur, Perfumer and Motivational Speaker. He is the founder and CEO of Sapphire scents, the first indigenous Perfume making company in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://justumagazine.com/the-master-perfumer-adewale-aladejana-c-e-o-sapphire-scents/|title=The Master Perfumer Adewale Aladejana C. E. O Sapphire Scents|publisher=}}</ref>
==Early Life and Education== Aladejana was born to a middle-class family as the 7th child in a family of nine children. He attended King's College, Lagos, and later International School, [[Ibadan]]. He has a Bachelors of Science degree in Mass Communication from [[Bowen University]].
==Career== Aladejana began his career with the TY Danjuma Foundation, a Non- Governmental Organization founded by Nigeria's former Chief of Army Staff [[Theophilus Danjuma]], as a Programs assistant in [[Benin]], South-South [[Nigeria]]. He moved to [[Abuja]], Nigeria's Federal Capital in 2012 where he started his perfume company, Sapphire scents with only $100 in 2015 but is now valued at over $10 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gistmania.com/talk/topic,334875.0.html|title=Billionaire, Adewale Aladejana Reveals How He Turned N30k Into Billions of Naira Within 2yrs -Photos - Gistmania|date=28 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref> His perfume is sold across Nigeria, the [[US]], [[Uk]], [[Ireland]], [[Cyprus]], [[Ghana]] and [[Cameroon]]. Aladejana has many times attributed the success of his company to God and to popular Abuja pastor, Biodun Fatoyinbo, who gave him 1 million naira in 2015 to expand his business.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://olorisupergal.com/2018/05/30/wale-aladejana-founder-of-sapphire-perfumes-praises-coza-pastor-for-blessing-his-business/|title=WALE ALADEJANA, FOUNDER OF SAPPHIRE PERFUMES PRAISES COZA PASTOR, FOR BLESSING HIS BUSINESS - Olori Supergal|date=2018-05-30|work=Olori Supergal|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref> Nollywood actress [[Tonto Dikeh]] became a brand ambassador of his company in 2018. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://punchng.com/dbanj-tonto-dikeh-celebrate-with-sapphire-scents/|title=D’banj, Tonto Dikeh celebrate with Sapphire Scents|website=Punchng.com}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2018/03/tonto-dike-sapphire-scents/|title=Tonto Dikeh is the Face of Sapphire Scents Bespoke Perfume - See her Must Watch Ad - BellaNaija|website=www.bellanaija.com}}</ref>

revision.text:
A '''work permit''' is the permission to take a [[job]] within a foreign country. It may also be a permit given to minors allowing them to work legally under [[child labor]] laws. Within an [[industry]], a work permit may be required to execute certain functions within a factory outside normal operational tasks (such as maintenance tasks) — in some places they might be called Permit to Work (PTW).
== European Union == {{see also|Blue Card (European Union)}} Currently, every EU country has a different process for granting work permits to nationals of non-EU countries. To address this issue, the European Commission began work in 1999 on developing an EU-wide process for the entry of non-EU nationals into the work force.<ref name="Towards a Common European Union Immigration Policy">{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice_home/fsj/immigration/fsj_immigration_intro_en.htm |title=Towards a Common European Union Immigration Policy |accessdate=2007-03-03 |publisher=European Commission}}</ref> In October 2007, they adopted a proposal to introduce a work permit similar to the United States' "Green Card" program, called the "Blue Card". It is similar to the UK's [[Highly Skilled Migrant Programme]], with the exception that it will require an employment contract in place prior to migration. After two years in the first country, the migrant will be allowed to move and work in another EU country, and can sum the number of years spent in the EU for purposes of residency. This new card will abolish work permits across the EU and centralize the issuing from Brussels. <ref name="EU Blue Card to encourage highly-qualified non-EU citizens to work in the EU">{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/ireland/press_office/news_of_the_day/bluecard_en.htm |title=EU Blue Card to encourage highly-qualified non-EU citizens to work in the EU |accessdate=2007-03-03 |publisher=European Commission, Irish Press Office}}</ref>
===Belgium=== {{main article|Work permit (Belgium)}}
===France=== The procedure to get a work permit is quite elaborate since the applicant should prove that no French jobseeker fitted the position.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alain-Christian |last=Monkam|title=How to get a work permit in France|website= Village de la Justice|year= 2011|url= http://www.village-justice.com/articles/permit-France,11079.html}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{main article|Work permit (United Kingdom)}} There are seven standard ways to apply for a work permit in the United Kingdom: the Business and Commercial Arrangements, the Training and Work Experience Arrangements, the Sports people and Entertainers Arrangements, Student Internships, GATS, Ancestry Visa and the Sectors Based Scheme. All applications require the work permit holder to leave the country where the work permit was issued every three months under the Work Permit Arrangements. Costs for leaving the airport are £64, per person and you must return to the airport after 24 hours or one working day to leave the country. If you remain in the airport the cost is £35 per person and you must leave the country after 24 hours or one working day in the airport. <ref name="Working in the UK - Work Permit Arrangements">{{cite web |url=http://www.workingintheuk.gov.uk/working_in_the_uk/en/homepage/work_permits0/applying_for_a_work.html |title=Working in the UK - Work Permit Arrangements |accessdate=2007-03-03 |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom}}</ref> Each of these involves its own application process, and generally requires a job offer from a UK employer.
UK Work visas allow for extended visa options which may lead to permanent residence. With Europe at its doorstep and a large domestic market, the various UK work visa categories offer a gateway for thousands of applicants seeking the experience of European life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.migrationexpert.co.uk/work_visa/|title= UK Work Visa - Visa Service & Advice Online|publisher=}}</ref>
The UK work permit system is currently being replaced by a new [[Points-based immigration system (United Kingdom)|points-based immigration system]].
==Russia== According to the Federal Migration Service of Russia estimates, Russia's 5 million foreign nationals work today.
In order to work in Russia, foreign citizen must have a work visa (visa for arriving at the order), to obtain a work permit and get on migration registration in the Russian Federal Migration Service bodies.
For foreign citizens arriving without visas ([[CIS countries]] except [[Turkmenistan]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]) there is a simplified procedure. The period of temporary stay for them is 90 days but can be extended up to one year from the date of entry into the Russian Federation on presentation of the migration service of the employment contract or a contract of civil-legal nature. That is, a foreigner can obtain a work permit for up to 90 days, and then to extend it after the job. However, it is recommended to immediately impose labor or civil contract and to issue a work permit for the duration of its validity.
Issuance of work permits is carried out taking into account the established quota. The quota is divided by region, Russia and the integrated vocational qualification groups.
A work permit is divided to some categories: *qualified professionals are employed by their existing profession (specialty), included in the approved list of professions (specialties, positions); *highly qualified professionals engaged in labor activity in accordance with the provisions of Article 13 of the Federal Law "On the Legal Status of Foreign Citizens in the Russian Federation." The work permit is valid within the subject of the Russian Federation, in which it was issued.
== Ukraine == Foreigners and [[Statelessness|stateless]] persons can be employed in [[Ukraine]] after obtaining an appropriate permit. These requirements are established by article 42 of the Law of Ukraine "On Employment"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.clc.co.ua/work-permit-in-ukraine/|title=Work permit in Ukraine. Obtaining and legislation.|last=Thor|first=Anatoliy|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. State Employment Service of Ukraine is the main authority to issue work permit.
Does not require obtaining a work permit for: * foreigners who have [[Permanent residency|residence permit]] in Ukraine; * [[Refugee|refugees]]; * foreigners who have permission to immigrate to Ukraine; * foreigners who are recognized as persons in need of additional protection, or who are granted temporary protection in Ukraine; * representatives of foreign maritime (river) fleet and airlines that serve such companies on the territory of Ukraine; * employees of foreign media who are accredited to work in Ukraine; * professional athletes, artists and art workers to work in Ukraine; * workers of emergency services for urgent work; * employees of foreign representative (branch) office that are registered in the territory of Ukraine in accordance with the procedure established by the law; * ecclesiastic who are to reside in Ukraine temporarily (on the ground of invitation of religious organization) for canonical activity only in such religious organization; * foreigners who arrived in Ukraine to participate in the implementation of international technical assistance projects; * foreigners who arrived in Ukraine to conduct teaching and / or scientific activities in higher education institutions; * other foreigners in cases provided by laws and international treaties of Ukraine; * Obtaining work permit in Ukraine<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.clc.co.ua/work-permit-in-ukraine/|title=Work permit in Ukraine. Legal services and advisory - Law Firm "Capital Law Consulting"|publisher=}}</ref> is one of the basics to obtain residence permit.
== United States == [[File:Getting_working_papers._New_York._-_NARA_-_523068.jpg|thumb|Applying for working papers, 1908 ([[United States Children's Bureau]])]] In general, the United States does not require work permits for adult [[Citizenship in the United States|citizen]]s. However, certain aliens are required to have an [[Employment Authorization Document]] from the [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]] (USCIS) of the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS).
The [[federal government of the United States]] does not require work permits or proof-of-age certificates for a minor to be employed.<ref name="dol_youth_certs">{{cite web | title= Youth & Labor: Work Permits & Age Certificates | url= http://www.dol.gov/dol/topic/youthlabor/workpermitsagecert.htm}}</ref> However, the possession of an age certificate constitutes a good faith effort to comply with minimum age requirements of the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] of 1938.<ref name="dol_youth_certs"/> The [[United States Department of Labor]] will issue a "certificate of age" if the minor employee's state does not issue them, or if the minor is requested by his or her employer to provide one.<ref name="dol_youth_certs"/><ref>{{USCFR|29|570}}</ref> Several states are not listed in {{USCFR|29|570|9}}(a), such as Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Kansas, Mississippi, South Carolina, Texas, and Utah, and thus their certificates may not meet the requirements of {{USCFR|29|570|5}}(b) as being evidence of compliance with the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Many states also require them for workers of certain ages.<ref name="dol_youth_certs"/> In some states, for example [[New Jersey]], permits are only required for minors 14 and 15 years old, while others such as [[Massachusetts]] require, at least in theory, work permits for all minors until they turn 18 years of age. In some states, enforcement is strict. Permits are usually issued through the school system the minor attends, and typically at a minimum is conditioned on enrollment in high school with regular attendance (no chronic absenteeism, tardiness, or truancy). Some states such as [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Indiana]] require high school students with part-time jobs to maintain a certain [[grade point average]]. Minors who are working are usually restricted in the number of hours each day or week they are permitted to work as well as the types of jobs they may hold.
== Turkey ==
The immigration in Turkey is regulated by the {{ill|General Directorate of Immigration Management|tr|Göç İdaresi Genel Müdürlüğü}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goc.gov.tr/main/Eng_3|title=Ministry Of Interior Directorate General Of Migration Management|website=www.goc.gov.tr}}</ref> (Göç İdaresi Genel Müdürlüğü) under the supervision of the [[Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)|Ministry of Interior]]<ref>http://www.mia.gov.tr/</ref> while work permits are delivered by the {{ill|General Directorate of Labor Immigration|tr|Uluslararası İşgücü Genel Müdürlüğü}} (Uluslararası İşgücü Genel Müdürlüğü) under the supervision of the [[Ministry of Labour and Social Security (Turkey)|Ministry of Labour and Social Security]] (Türkiye Cumhuriyeti Çalışma ve Sosyal Güvenlik Bakanlığı).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csgb.gov.tr/En|title=T.C. ÇALIŞMA VE SOSYAL GÜVENLİK BAKANLIĞI - Anasayfa|first=T.C. Çalışma ve Sosyal Güvenlik Bakanlığı - Bilgi İşlem Daire Başkanlığı, İnternet Hizmetleri Şubesi|last=Müdürlüğü|website=www.csgb.gov.tr}}</ref> All applications for both residence permit and work permit are made through online government portals. The residence permit application is made through " "e-Residence" (e-İkamet)<ref>https://e-ikamet.goc.gov.tr/</ref> while {{ill|Turkish work permit|tr|Türkiye'de çalışma izni}} application are made through [[e-Government (Turkey)]] (e-Devlet).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.turkiye.gov.tr/|title=e-Devlet Kapısı Devletin Kısayolu - www.türkiye.gov.tr|website=www.turkiye.gov.tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.expatguideturkey.com/acquisition-of-turkish-citizenship-i/|title=CITIZENSHIP IN TURKEY|newspaper=Expat Guide Turkey|language=tr-TR|access-date=2016-10-31}}</ref>
==South Africa== There are three categories of South African work visa or permit available to a foreigner each with its own set of specific requirements all assisting in immigration to South Africa or working in South Africa. These are the ''General Work Visa/Permit'', the ''Critical Skills Work Visa/Permit'' and the ''Intra-Company Transfer Work Visa/Permit''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Work Permits in South Africa |url=http://www.immigrationsouthafrica.org/work-permit-south-africa/ |accessdate=2015-07-08 |publisher=Immigration South Africa™}}</ref> Due to recent immigration law changes (May, 2014), the obtaining of work visas or permits in South Africa has become much more arduous. Furthermore, these work permits are now referred to as visas.
'''General Work Visa/Permit''' - The basis of a general work visa/permit is that a firm offer of employment has been made by a prospective employer to a foreigner after such employer has unsuccessfully exploited the local labour market in attempting to procure the needed skills, experiences or qualifications equivalent of such foreigner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigrationsouthafrica.org/general-work-visa-south-africa/|title=General Work Visa - Immigration South Africa™|website=www.immigrationsouthafrica.org}}</ref>
'''Critical Skills Work Visa/Permit''' - A critical skills work permit may be issued to a foreigner who possesses critical skills or qualifications and is able to demonstrate with supporting documentation in the form of testimonials, publications. This is based on a list published by the Department of Home Affairs in South Africa called the Critical Skills List <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigrationsouthafrica.org/Critical_Skills_Work_Visa_List.pdf|title=South Africa's latest Critical Skills List (PDF)|publisher=}}</ref> A letter of motivation from an authoritative body to substantiate the benefits that those skills will bring to South Africa. This critical skills work permit is granted for up to five years and may be renewed for a further period, if required.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigrationsouthafrica.org/critical-skills/|title=Critical Skills Work Visa - Immigration South Africa™|website=www.immigrationsouthafrica.org}}</ref> This visa type replaces the previously issued Quota Work Permit and the Exceptional Skills Work Permit.
'''Intra-Company Transfer Work Visa/Permit''' - An intra company transfer work permit is issued to a foreigner who is normally deployed or seconded to South African branch, subsidiary or associate office of a corporate entity aboard. There are strict controls to ensure that the foreigner remains employed in his or her specific position during the tour of duty. This type of visa is only valid for two years, and often no extension is possible. Also, any applicant must have first worked for a minimum of 6 months in the employ of the company’s foreign office before applying to relocate and immigrate to the South African branch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigrationsouthafrica.org/work-permit-south-africa/|title=Work Visas for South Africa - Immigration South Africa™|website=www.immigrationsouthafrica.org}}</ref>
==Canada== Canada work permits are issued under the Temporary Foreign Worker Program (TFWP) by Canada immigration and Citizenship.
The TFWP has four streams: high-skilled workers, low-skilled workers, the Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program, and the Live-In Caregiver Program.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Singer|first1=Colin|title=Canada Work Permit|url=http://www.immigration.ca/canada-work-visa/|website=immigration.ca}}</ref>
==Singapore== In Singapore, the work permit process is managed by the Ministry of Manpower. There are several kinds of work permits,<ref>{{cite web |title=Passes and Visas (Singapore)|url=http://www.mom.gov.sg/foreign-manpower/passes-visas/Pages/default.aspx |accessdate=2012-05-06 |publisher=SingaporeMinistry of Manpower}}</ref> and the type accorded generally depends on the salary range of the position, as well as on skills (including education), work experience, and the type of job being applied for. These work permit types include the Employment Pass (monthly salary of at least S$4,000), S Pass (monthly salary of at least S$2,800), and "Work Permit" (generally for unskilled workers).{{cn|date=August 2017}}
For skilled personnel such as confinement nannies from Malaysia, the work permit is short-term. Employers or appointed agencies are able to hire Malaysian confinement nanny<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nannysos.com.sg/confinement-nanny-work-permit-singapore|title= Confinement Nanny Work Permit Singapore|author=|date=|work= Confinement NannySOS |accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref> by applying the work permit either online or manually. The validity period can be up to 16 weeks with reference to the birth time of the child. There are two situations which the pass can be extended. It is either when the required employment period is longer than the issued permit or when the confinement nanny leaves Singapore during her employment period.
Another kind of work permit available in Singapore commonly known as the EntrePass and is especially geared towards entrepreneurs who might not pass the stringent requirements regarding education and salary. The EntrePass is for foreign entrepreneurs who are planning to start up a business in Singapore. The entrepreneur must be actively involved in operations of the business. Candidates can apply for this anytime up until 6 months after they registered the business. Generally EntrePass are awarded to individuals who have either have a proven track record of running successful businesses or who have an innovative idea. The Singapore Personalised Employment Pass, also known as PEP is a special type of Singapore work visa issued to individuals based on their own merits. The issuance of the PEP is managed by Singapore’s Ministry of Manpower. The PEP is independent of any employer, rendering a PEP holder the flexibility and freedom to switch employers without having the pass revoked. The PEP holder is also entitled to stay in Singapore for up to 6 months in between jobs and to evaluate career opportunities. It is issued for a period of 5 years, and non renewable thereafter. But, since December 2011, PEP has been discontinued by the Singaporean Authority.<ref>{{cite web |title=Personalised Employment Pass (Singapore) |url=http://www.mom.gov.sg/foreign-manpower/passes-visas/personalised-employment/before-you-apply/Pages/default.aspx |accessdate=2012-05-06 |publisher=Singapore Ministry of Manpower}}</ref>
=== Hazardous === A work permit system is a formal written system to control certain types of work identified as potentially hazardous. The terms "P.T.W.", "permit" or "work permit" refer to the form used by a company to meet its needs. These systems aim to ensure proper planning and consideration of the risks involved in a particular job, at a specific time and place, with designated precautions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Guidelines on permit to Work (P.T.W.) systems |url=http://www.ogp.org.uk/pubs/189.pdf |accessdate=2012-09-18 |publisher=International Association of Oil & Gas Producers}}</ref>
It is usually categorized in "hot" work permits and "cold" work permits. Hot works are those where there is a potential of generating fire or extreme heat, cold ones are all the others.
==Australia== Several different types of visas are available for immigrants. {{cn|date=November 2017}}
== Thailand == Foreigners holding a "B" visa and wishing to work or start a business in Thailand are required to obtain a work permit. The issuance of work permits is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Labor of Thailand. Work without permission in the Kingdom is criminally punishable. It takes 7 working days to process the application for a permit. If the applicant is qualified and able to use "One Stop Service Center", the work permit will only take one day.
=== Duties === '''Thai government fees for a work permit:''' *100 Baht/form = Permit application Fee. *750 Baht = work permit not longer than 3 months. *1,500 Baht = work permit longer than 3 months but does not exceed 6 months. *3,000 Baht = work permit longer than 6 months but does not exceed 12 months. '''Thai government fees for amendments:''' *500 Baht/Book = Substitute of a permit. *1,000 Baht/time = Permission to change or add job description. *3,000 Baht/time = Permission to remove or add an employer. *1,000 Baht/time = Permission to change or add the locality or place of work. *150 Baht/time = Permission to change or add conditions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gam-legalalliance.com/services/immigration/thai-visas/thai-work-permit/work-permit-fees-in-thailand/|title=Work Permit Fees in Thailand {{!}} G.A.M. Legal Alliance|publisher=gam-legalalliance.com|lang=en|accessdate=2018-09-11}}</ref> According to the Emergency Decree on Non-Thais' Working Management No. 2, 2018, foreigners can work anywhere in the country without having to record these changes in the permit, but each employer must be listed in the book. If the employee is transferred to another office in another part of the country, the employer should notify the office of the Employment Department.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Phuket News: New Work Permit rules confirmed by Phuket Employment Office Chief|first=The Phuket News|last=Com|url=https://www.thephuketnews.com/new-work-permit-rules-confirmed-by-phuket-employment-office-chief-68463.php#hKPzXuOSWSyAwLX3.97|work=The Phuket News Com|accessdate=2018-09-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
